summary: Day 1 - The first superhero you ever saw This one’s a firm shout out to the 90s spider man tv show, my older brother had a...
caption:
Day 1 - The first superhero you ever saw

This one’s a firm shout out to the 90s spider man tv show, my older brother had a couple of spider man vhs tapes that I used to mooch off and rewatch all the time. 

I ended up watching what I now know was the second and third episodes of Spider Man: The Animated Series season two. 

That was my introduction to Spidey and to Superheroes in general.

In the first part:
After a battle with Dr. Octopus where a medical research building is destroyed. Blaming himself, Peter is considering giving up being Spider-Man, when he meets an inter-dimensional being named Madame Web who encourages him to regain faith in what he does by sending him to meet a little girl (and his biggest fan) called Taina. Spider-Man shares his origin story with her. And Dr. Octopus attacks with his new invention the Octobot.

  • Based on Amazing Fantasy #15 and The Amazing Spider-Man #55 and #248.

And in the second part: 
Found the source of my love for the plot convenience amnesia trope.
During Spider-Man’s battle with the Octobot, Doc Ock he uses a nerve nullifying blaster to give him amnesia.
Dr Octopus takes advantage of this and convinces Spider-Man that he’s his personal assistant and goes on a crime spree. Taina manages to get help from Mousey a Jamaican Taxi Driver who convinces all the taxi drivers in New York to help them by turning into a kind of information net on the look out for Spider Man all over the city. Taina manages to get Spidey to remember his true self; he then returns her back to her room, where he even reveals his true identity to her. Taina promises never to tell anyone. Spidey thinks to himself that Taina was a bigger hero than him. The last scene of the episode shows her is in a facility for terminally ill children - meeting Spidey was her last wish which is an added sucker punch that I did not process at all as a little kid myself, I completely didn’t realise she was terminally ill until I looked up the episode again for this… Ouch!

  • Based on The Amazing Spider-Man #56 and #248.
